Name: ozone
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 1 based on rat LC50 value of 4.8ppm (ACGIH (2001).)

Name: Hydrobromic acid
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 3 based on rat inhalation LC50 = 1430ppm (4hr) (ACGIH (2004)).

Name: Chlorine dioxide
Rationale for classification: It was considerd as Category 1 based on rat LC50 (4 hours) value: 32ppm (CICAD 37, 2002).

Name: Nitrogen monoxide
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 3 from the rat value of 870ppm (RTECS (2004)).

Name: nitrogen dioxide
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 1 based on rat LC50 (4 hours) value: 88ppm (RTECS, 2005, HSDB, 2005) and rat LC50 (1 hour) value: 0.22mg/L (4-hour equivalent of 58ppm) (RTECS, 2005).

Name: boron trichloride
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 3 based on rat LC50 value of 1270ppm/4H (2541ppm/1H) (HSDB, 2002).

Name: Dimethylamine
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 4 based on rat LC50 (4 hours) value: 4700 ml/m3 (DFGOT vol.7 (1996)).

Name: diborane(6)
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 1 based on the lower rat inhalation LC50 value (4hrs) = 40ppm (from the two-point data of 40ppm (ACGIH (2001)) and 50ppm (PATTY (5th, 2001)).

Name: sulphuryl difluoride
Rationale for classification: Rad LC50 value (4-hour equivalent) = 1865ppm (male) and 1510ppm (female) (all are ACGIH(s) (7th, 2001)) (in the information on Priority 1), and the higher toxic value (1510ppm) was adopted, and it was considered as Category 3.

Name: carbonyl difluoride
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 2 based on the lower value from rat LC50 (1 hour) value= 360ppm (4-hour equivalent of 180ppm), and 460ppm (4-hour equivalent of 230ppm) (ACGIH 7th, 2001, PATTY 4th, 1994).

Name: Perfluoroisobutylene
Rationale for classification: Boiling points is 7degC in 760torr, and it is gas according to GHS definition. It was considered as Category 1 based on rat 2 hour exposure LC50 value: 1.05ppm (4 hour equivalent: 0.742ppm) (ACGIH 7th, 2001)(in source of Priority 1).

Name: Cyanamide
Rationale for classification: Solutions is outside of classification since it is the liquid based on GHS definition. Since there is no data about active ingredient,  it cannot be classified.

Name: oxalonitrile
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 2 based on rat inhalation exposures LC50= 175ppm (4-hour equivalent) (Patty (5th, 2001)).

Name: Ketene
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 1based on lower LC50 = 51ppm. (from two data obtained by having converted rat LC50 value into 4 hours exposure.

Name: Formaldehyde
Rationale for classification: Based on the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of gas) of 480ppm (SIDS (2002)).

Name: cyanogen chloride
Rationale for classification: Mouse lethal concentration (3-minute exposure) = 500ppm (ACGIH (2001)). (If it converts, it will be <100ppm as 4 hours exposure.) There is also a descriptions of death (ACGIH (2001)) by 48ppm and exposure for 30 minute for humans. It was considered as Category 1 based on these knowledge.

Name: methyl nitrite
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 2 from rat LC50 = 176ppm/4H (PATTY, 5th (2001), RTECS (1997)).

Name: Carbon monoxide
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 3 from data of rat LC50 (4hr): 1805ppm (IUCLID (2000)) and 1659ppm (RTECS (2004)).

Name: hexafluoroacetone
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 2 based on the description that the rat lethal concentration in 4-hour exposure is 300ppm (ACGIH 7th, 2001).

Name: Bromomethane; Methyl bromide
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation of gas) value of 600ppm (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1980)).

Name: Chloromethane; Methyl chloride
Rationale for classification: Based on the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of gas) of 2,566ppm (SIDS (2004)), representing the lower of the two testing data, 2,566mg/kg (SIDS (2004)) and 2,700mg/kg (SIDS (2004)).

Name: Methanamine
Rationale for classification: Since LC50 values of the 4-hour inhalation exposure test employing rats were 4,400 mL/m3 (4,400 ppm), and 6,400-9,100 mL/m3 (6,400-9,100 ppm) (DFGOT vol.7 (1996)), it was classified into Category 4.

Name: Methanethiol
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 3. Based on Rat LC50 (4 hours) value: 675ppm (ACGIH, 2004, DFGOT vol.20, 2003, PATTY 4th, 1994, ATSDR, 1992) and LC50 (1 hour) value: 1680ppm (4-hour equivalent of 840 ppm)( DFGOT vol.20, 2003, PATTY 4th, 1994).

Name: Sulfur dioxide
Rationale for classification: LC50 value of the study was judged to 593 - 1319ppm, and it was considered as Category 3. This is from description that death is not observed at 593ppm, three of eight examples died at 965ppm, five of eight examples died at 1168ppm, and the all eight examples died at 1319ppm in the rat 4-hour inhalation exposure test (ATSDR (1998)).

Name: Ethanamine
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 5 based on rat LC50 = 6842ppm (IUCLID (2000)).

Name: Ethylene oxide
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 800ppm representing the lower of the two testing data, 1,460ppm (CaPSAR, 1999) and 800ppm ((MOE Risk Assessment Vol. 2, 2003).

Name: Phosgene
Rationale for classification: Based on human LC50 (inhalation of gas) value of 2ppm (4 hours: converted from 170 min), representing the two testing data, rat LC50 of 5.58ppm (4 hours) (CERI Hazard Data 2000-51 (2001)) and human LC50 of 3ppm (170 min).

Name: Trimethylamine
Rationale for classification: It is classified into Category 4 based on the lower value (LC50 = 3519ppm) among two rat LC50 = 3519ppm (IUCLID, 2000) and 4264ppm (IUCLID, 2000)(in the source of Priority 2).

Name: Borane, trifluoro-
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 2 based on rat LC50 = 436ppm (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Hydrochloric acid
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 3, based on 1411ppm obtained from the statistical calculations after conversion from rat LC50 = 4.2, 4.7 and 283mg/L/60min (SIDS (2002)). In addition, since it became lower than the lowest value of calculated data, lowest value 4.2mg/L (4-hour product portfolio managements equivalents 1411ppm) of data is adopted.

Name: Ammonia
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 4 based on rat LC50 = 4608.7ppm (4-hour equivalent) (EHC 54 (1986)).

Name: Fluorine
Rationale for classification: Based on the LC50 (4 hours) of 92.5ppm calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (1-hour inhalation of gas) of 185ppm (PATTY  (4th, 2000)).

Name: Chlorine
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 2 based on each 4-hour equivalent of two data of a rat being LC50 = 146ppm (EHC 21 (1982), ACGIH (2005)).

Name: germanium tetrahydride
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 1 based on guinea pigs LC50 value = 260mg/m3 (equivalent: 83ppm) (RTECS (2004)) in the 4-hour inhalation experiments.

Name: Hydrogen sulfide
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Catgory 2 based on the lower value of 444ppm. ( from rat LC50 (4 hours): 444ppm (industrial hygene academic society recommentation (2001), ACGIH (2001)), and 700mg/m3 (equivalent: 503ppm) (CICAD (2003)).

Name: phosphorous trifluoride
Rationale for classification: There was no data of LC50. So it was estimated by mouse LCLo = 33.52ppm/4H (equivalent) (RTECS (2004)), and it was considered as Category 1.

Name: sulphur tetrafluoride
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 1 from rat LC50 = 19ppm/4hr (ACGIH (7th, 2001)).

Name: Selenium hexafluoride
Rationale for classification: There was no data of LC50. So It was estimated by rat LCLo = 5ppm/4H (equivalent) (RTECS (2004)), and it was considered as Category 1. In addition, it support the category 1that 10ppm/4H exposure was also lethal in any four sorts of the rat, the mouse, the guinea pig, and the rabbit (HSDB, 2003).

Name: Tungsten hexafluoride
Rationale for classification: Based on the LC50 value of 117ppm calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 of 1.43mg/L (HSDB (2004)).

Name: Arsine
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation of gas) value of 16.2ppm (4 hours).

Name: chlorine trifluoride
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 2 based on rat LC50 = 149ppm.

Name: phosphine
Rationale for classification: It was considered as Category 1 based on rat LC50 (4 hours) level: 11ppm (EHC 73, 1988, ACGIH 7th, 2001, industrial hygene academic society recommentation, 1998).

Name: silane
Rationale for classification: It become out of Category 4 according to rat LC50 = 9600ppm/4hr (ACGIH (7th, 2001)) (Priority 1 document). But rat LC50 = 4000ppm/4hr (HSDB (2005)) (Priority 2 document) are suitable for Category 4. And there are the nonsurviving animals up to the dose to Category 4, it was considered as Category 5.
